About me
I am a researcher with more than 15 years experience answering questions about communication, perception, and movement. I love figuring out how to ask the right questions, collect useful data, and set up informative models. I have worked in diverse settings and I have collaborated with engineers, neuroscientists, physicians, and rehabilitation professionals. What keeps me motivated is the joy of collaborating with a team and constant learning.
I have led projects examining sensorimotor control of speech, predicting diagnoses from acoustic measures, and improving clinical outcomes measurement. These projects have allowed me to develop and leverage skills including research design, statistical modeling (t test, ANOVA, linear and logistic regression, structural equation modeling, nonparametric statistics, ICCs) and coding (R, SPSS, Stata), scripting (MATLAB), signal acquisition and processing (acoustic, aerodynamic, surface electromyography), data visualization, technical writing, and science communication. I also have extensive experience with mentorship and teaching in research, clinic, and classroom settings.
Please feel free to contact me if you would like to learn more or discuss potential projects.

title: Projects
text:
When we move our bodies, our brains make predictions about sensations associated with that movement, and we compare those predictions with our actual sensory feedback. If there is a mismatch between prediction and reality, we use that information to help learn and refine movements. For speech, the most important feedback is auditory. In the lab, we can create artificial mismatches by altering auditory feedback and playing it back to a person on headphones in real time while they speak (think autotune!). We use these experiments to learn more about how the brain controls movements for speech.
In one project, I looked at how reliable these experiments are when they are repeated over time in the same individuals. In another project, I am measuring how people with voice disorders respond to altered auditory feedback compared to people with typical voices, and measuring changes in muscle activation around the voice box when they hear altered feedback. I am also measuring how well people can hear differences in pitch and loudness and looking for relationships with their vocal behavior. These studies are helping us to understand why people develop voice disorders, and may lead to new methods of diagnosis and treatment.

title: Projects
section: Predicting Voice Disorder Status From Acoustic Measures
text:
Predicting Voice Disorder Status From Acoustic Measures


Voice disorders cause people to have poor voice quality (i.e., hoarseness) and vocal fatigue, which makes it difficult to communicate. The most common types of voice disorders involve excessive muscle tension in the voice box. However, this is difficult to measure. One type of acoustic measure, called relative fundamental frequency (RFF), is thought to be sensitive to tension in the voice box. Another acoustic measure, called cepstral peak prominence (CPP), can detect poor voice quality. I tested whether a combination of features related to RFF and CPP could predict whether a person had a voice disorder in a large sample of voice recordings. We found that the combination of measures had good predictive performance and worked better than either type of measure alone. This type of measure is accessible, inexpensive, and non-invasive and could be useful for screening people at high risk of voice disorders.

title: Projects
section: Measuring Outcomes and Understanding Patient Experiences
text:
Measuring Outcomes and Understanding Patient Experiences


When you make a change and you want to know if it had the desired effect, you need measurement tools that are valid and reliable. You also need to know how people’s perspectives might be different depending on their experience. It might even affect the results you get from your measurement tools! One way that we measure voice disorders is by listening to the voice and rating things like breathiness or roughness. In one project, I showed that ratings are impacted by listener experience, and clinicians and patients may actually be rating different things. I have also shown how we can change measurement tools to make those ratings more similar, and to improve reliability.
Questionnaires are another useful tool for measuring outcomes. I have collaborated on projects using a combination of qualitative and quantitative methods to understand patient experiences and to validate a patient-reported outcome measure for people with communication disorders.
